Recalling Recognition Justice

  • Misrecognition can occur via three processes:
  • Figueroa (2006) defines misrecognition as rooted in environmental identity + heritage.

Whyte‚Äôs Recognition Paradigm

  • ‚ÄúParadigm‚Äù refers to a criterion that can be used to identify whether an unjust process is occurring.
    • Distributional paradigm
    • Procedural paradigm
    • Recognition paradigm
  • Examples of each?

Intro to Community Case Study

  • Example of all five EJ tenets
  • Pasqualetti, et al. (2016) asks, why hasn‚Äôt more RE been developed on Tribal lands, specifically in Navajo Nation?
    • Relationship to extractive energy development
    • Spiritual and social values
    • Energy governance

Navajo Nation

  • Din√© translates to ‚Äúthe people‚Äù
  • Located in three corners: Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico
  • Biggest Tribe in terms of:
    • Area: Size of Ireland (2.5x state of Massachusetts)
    • Population: 300,000+ members
  • Young population, high unemployment rates (48.5%, 11x national average), and low household income ($8,250 annually, 10% of national average).
  • Complex history of coal and uranium mining

Energy Extractivism on Navajo Lands

  • Highest value of economic activity for decades has been fossil fuel/mining.
  • Long history of Navajo Nation fighting for control of their land‚Äôs mineral resources.
    • Coal slurry (mix of coal + water shipped to NV, hugely depleting groundwater)
    • Subbituminous coal mining (Significant air pollution)
    • Uranium mining and milling (environmental health risks)

Solar Paradox of Plenty

  • Navajo Nation solar potential is 100x the installed capacity of California.
    • Navajo Nation wasn‚Äôt included in REA of 1935.
    • Roughly 1/3 of Navajo Nation homes don‚Äôt have electricity today.
    • Matrilineal spiritual + ancestral grazing lands are very remote.

Spiritual Ties

  • K‚Äô√© is Navajo word for kinship, applies to human and non-human relationships.
  • H√≥zh√≥ focuses on environmental preservation.
    • Navajo people are likely to place more importance on future costs to the environment than promise of employment/economic benefit.

Energy Governance

  • Tribal Lands are a mix of Public, Tribal Trust, Tribal Fee, Bureau of Land Management (BLM), Private, State (3 states), and BIA Indian Allotments
    • This makes governance very challenging.
    • Some Federal processes and policies apply to Tribal lands
    • States have little authority over Tribal lands
    • Navajo Nation Codes regulate RE development, 110 chapter governments often have final say via approval rights

Solar in Navajo Nation

  • Do any forms of misrecognition (cultural domination, non-recognition, disrespect) apply to Pasqualetti‚Äôs piece?
  • Do any of the other four tenets apply to this case study?
  • How does scale factor in to EJ implications of solar (i.e., distributed, community, utility-scale)?

Beshilas et al., 2023

Off-Grid in the Chuskas

  • Short piece in ‚ÄúLandscapes of Power‚Äù
    • Powell stays off-grid in Hogan with Adella Begaye
    • Details Angie + Jay‚Äôs experience as seasonal sheep + goat herders
  • Describes heterogeneity in NN lives; energy preferences for independence, environmental heritages and livelihoods, modernity versus tradition

Processes for Solar + Recognition Justice?

  • What aspects of decisionmaking should be prioritized for the Navajo Nation‚Äôs energy transition?
    • Energy legacies
    • Environmental heritage
    • Governance
    • Self-Determination
  • If we were part of a community organization to increase solar uptake among NN households, what might our logic model look like (inputs, activities, outcomes)?
